title: 112_hr266
content: The Act titled "District of Columbia Equal Representation Act of 2011" provides representation in Congress for the District of Columbia. The "District of Columbia Equal Representation Act of 2011" grants the District of Columbia representation in Congress as a State for both the House of Representatives and the Senate. In the first election of Senators from the District of Columbia, the 2 senatorial offices will be separately identified and designated. No person can be a candidate for both offices. The Act grants the District of Columbia representation in Congress for both the House of Representatives and the Senate. It includes provisions for determining the class of Senators elected and making amendments related to the apportionment of members of the House of Representatives. Title 3, United States Code, is amended to include provisions for the District of Columbia. Conforming amendments are made regarding appointments to service academies in the United States military and naval academies. The United States Code is amended to include provisions for the District of Columbia, specifically regarding appointments to service academies in the military and naval academies. Amendments are made to Section 9342 of title 10, United States Code, with an effective date tied to the start of the One Hundred Twelfth Congress. Increase in membership of House of Representatives. The House of Representatives will have 436 members, including those representing the District of Columbia. The reapportionment of members will be based on the new number established for the One Hundred Twelfth Congress. The reapportionment of members for the House of Representatives will be based on the regular decennial census conducted for 2020 and subsequent ones. Repeal of the Office of District of Columbia Delegate and provision for elections for House members and Senators from District of Columbia. Effective date tied to the start of the One Hundred Twelfth Congress. The District of Columbia Elections Code of 1955 is amended to replace references to the Delegate to Congress with "the Representative in the Congress, Senator." This change applies to various sections of the code, including the heading of section 8. The District of Columbia Elections Code of 1955 is amended to replace references to the Delegate to Congress with "the Representative in the Congress, Senator." This change applies to various sections of the code, including section 10. The District of Columbia Elections Code of 1955 is amended to address vacancies in the office of Representative in Congress and Senator. The Mayor will appoint a successor to complete the remainder of the term of office in the event of a vacancy in the office of Senator. The District of Columbia Elections Code of 1955 is amended to replace references to "Delegate" with "Representative in the Congress, Senator" in various sections. These amendments will apply to future elections of Representatives and Senators from the District of Columbia. SEC. 6. REPEAL OF OFFICES OF STATEHOOD REPRESENTATIVE AND SENATOR. The text chunk discusses amendments to the District of Columbia Statehood Constitutional Convention Initiative of 1979, including changes to the number of voting members in the Statehood commission and the authorization of appropriations. The amendments made to the District of Columbia Statehood Constitutional Convention Initiative of 1979 include repealing sections related to appropriations, honoraria limitations, campaign finance laws, and the District of Columbia Elections Code of 1955. The effective date of these amendments is upon the taking office of the first Representative and Senators from the District of Columbia pursuant to this Act. SEC. 7. EXPEDITED JUDICIAL REVIEW. If any challenge to the constitutionality of this Act or its amendments is filed, it will be heard by a 3-judge court in the United States District Court for the District of Columbia. The House of Representatives and the Senate must be notified, and the final decision can only be appealed directly to the Supreme Court within specific time frames. The United States District Court for the District of Columbia and the Supreme Court of the United States are required to prioritize and expedite the resolution of any legal actions or appeals related to the constitutionality of the Act or its amendments. SEC. 8. NONSEVERABILITY OF PROVISIONS: If certain sections or amendments of the Act are deemed invalid, the remaining provisions and amendments will also be considered invalid and have no legal effect.
